Based on the nature of warehousing, the actual volume at the facility may be either greater than, or less than, the threshold level on any given day.  Based on a worst case scenario, the maximum that can be expected to be on site is 250,000 lbs (based on maximum propellant fill of 30% and our maximum storage capacity of 801,000 pounds of aerosol products), with the typical expected maximum amount to be closer to 50,000 (based on the typical propellant fill rate of 6%).

The regulated substance can be found throughout the facility, though the vast majority is stored in an ¿aerosol room¿ which was built to NFPA standards for aerosol warehousing.  Among the features built into this room are the use of ¿blast walls¿ to separate it from the main warehousing areas, fire doors that ¿automatically¿ close in the event of a major fire; extra sprinkler system capacity.  In addition the sprinkler system is fed through an on-site water retention pond which is maintained at an appropriate level via rainfall and a pump system.  The retention pond is also connected to a hydrant which can be accessed by the fire department.  In addition, the retention pond is located close to the aerosol room providing a ready source of water for additional fire fighting operations.

Storage of the substance outside of this room is limited to levels permitted by NFPA standards for ¿general¿ warehouses and is done for the purpose of small order processing including less than pallet quantities and single case shipments.

General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

Pursuant to our accidental release prevention policy, there are two major components to our accidental release prevention program.

  I.  Evaluation of Conditions of the Facility and Implementation of Improvements

The facility is evaluated by several different groups within the company, each

y.  These emergencies include fire, material releases, and severe weather.  Training in these procedures is company-wide and is both instructional (classroom based) and practical (drill based).

Fire

In the event of a fire involving or threatening to involve the regulated substance, the discovering associate determines if the fire is a ¿small¿ fire, or a ¿large¿ fire.  If the associate determines it is a small fire, the associate responds by utilizing the appropriate fire extinguisher to put out the fire.  If the associate determines it is a ¿large¿ fire, the associate implements our evacuation procedure and the local fire department is contacted.

Training associated with this emergency includes:
¿ Fire size/risk evaluation
¿ Evacuation procedures and routes of egress
¿ Fire extinguisher type, application and use

Material Release

In the event of a release of the regulated substance the discovering associate determines if the release is a minor or a major release.  If the associate determines it is a ¿minor¿ release, the immediate area of the release is evacuated and ventilated.   Following ventilation, associates perform clean-up activities while wearing appropriate safety equipment.  If the associate determines it is a ¿major¿ release, or that it appears that a ¿major¿ release is imminent the facility is evacuated and the local fire department is contacted.  It should be noted that the full release from a single container of the regulated substance would be considered a ¿minor¿ release, and any ¿major¿ release involving the regulated substance would require the release of the substance from a number of containers and may be expect to occur in the event of either a fire or a result of severe weather.

Training associated with this emergency includes:
¿ Release size/risk evaluation
¿ Evacuation procedures and routes of egress
¿ Spill Clean-Up methods

Severe Weather

In the event of severe weather, associate relocate to designated areas to wait out the severe wea

ther conditions.  If the severe weather does not damage the facility, associates return to activities following notice that the severe weather has passed.  If the severe weather damages the facility, associates evacuate the facility upon notice that the severe weather has passed, and the local fire department is contacted.

Training associated with this emergency includes:
¿ Severe weather response monitoring
¿ Location of designated shelter areas
¿ Evacuation procedures and routes of egress

As the local fire department is a integral part of our emergency response procedures we work in conjunction with both Green Oak Township Fire Department and the Livingston County LEPC to ensure that responders have the information and equipment to provide the services we may require of them.  Information concerning the facility is provided to the LEPC and fire department by the Regulatory Affairs Coordinator through our annual submissions of Tier II reports as well as the completion of periodic fire department surveys.

Planned changes to improve safety

At this time there are no changes under consideration for safety improvement and there are no outstanding recommendations that have not been resolved.

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

Our accidental releases prevention policy is to evaluate conditions at the facility, implement reasonable improvements to mitigate risks, and train associates in procedures developed to minimize and manage the risk of accidental releases due to their assigned job duties.

Our emergency response policy is to evaluate the emergency, respond to minor situations internally, and to rely on structural features and our local emergency responders for all other situations.

Business Overview of the stationary source and regulated substances handled

The facility is a warehousing operation.  The bulk of the operation is the movement of packaged goods from trucks, to racking and floor storage, and back to trucks.  Additional activities include the ¿building of mixed pallets¿ and the processing of single case shipments.  No repackaging is done, except for the processing of damaged/returned materials.  Repackaging is limited to the boxing/re-boxing of containers and the transference of liquids from damaged containers to secure containers.

There is only one regulated substance stored at the facility at amounts approaching, or exceeding, the threshold levels listed in 40 CFR 68.  This is a flammable mixture containing both propane and isobutene.  This mixture is used as the propellant in a number of the aerosol products stored at the facility.  These products are typically brake parts and specialty cleaners, lubricating oils, paints, and polishes.  These products packaged in consumer size cans ranging from 4 oz to 20 oz and are packed in DOT 2P and/or 2Q cans and are packed 6 or 12 cans per shipping case.  As a result of this packaging, the distance to the endpoint of any single container release is less than 0.01 miles (53 ft).  This means that all release are expected to reach their endpoints prior to being released from the building proper so there are no expected public receptors to our operations regulated under

of which is charged with making recommendations for improvement to Excelda¿s Executive Committee(EC) which determines the reasonability and feasibility of the recommendation and acts upon them accordingly. 
 
The first group is the Steering-Safety Team (SST).  The primary focus of this group is the safety of associates and the safety of our facility.  The group receives the results of the formal monthly safety walks which are conducted to identify any conditions that might result in a release such as ¿buckling uprights¿, ¿broken pallets on top racks¿, as well as to identify any possible improvements in the storage of the substance or the infrastructure of the storage locations.  In addition, the SST receives suggestions from associates which may also pertain to the storage and/or handling of the regulated substance.  

The second group is the Environmental Management System Team.  The primary focus of this group is minimizing the adverse environmental impacts of operations including how to prevent releases of materials.  This group receives the results of both the monthly safety walks and the semi-annual regulatory walkthroughs which are conducted as part of our ISO 14001 Environmental Management System to identify any conditions that fails to comply with applicable regulations and/or adopted industrial standards.

The third group is the Safety Coordinator & Facility Services Manager.  The primary focus of this group is to coordinate with the local fire department.  This group receives the results of the annual fire department inspections that are conducted by the Green Oak Fire Department as well as the results of the annual inspections of our fire alarm system, sprinkler system and pumps.  While these results are typically reported to the SST, this group may contact the EC directly.

The final group is the Executive Committee which directly receives the results of the periodic inspections that are conducted by our insurance carrier.

Results of this evaluation pr

ocess have included such previous implementation activities as:

¿ The addition of strobe lighting and additional alarms to assist in evacuations.
¿ The dredging of the fire water retention pond.
¿ The use of safety screens on high level racks containing unwrapped pallets to prevent cases from falling from heights
¿ The bracing of back-to-back free standing racking to keep racks from shifting so that racked pallets are not ¿pushed off¿ when a pallet is being added to the rack ¿behind¿ it
¿ The setting of  the ¿aerosol room¿ as an ¿off-limits¿ location to all powered equipment except for properly rated electrical equipment unless a ¿special permit¿ has been issued for a specific task, similar to a ¿hot work permit¿

 II.  Associate Training

Accidental release prevention training is conducted both on a general company-wide basis as well as on a job specific basis.

General company-wide training consists of training for every associate at the facility including those who are not expected to come in contact with the regulated substance on a regular basis.  This training includes:
¿ How to conduct a safety walk
¿ The smoking policy at the facility
¿ Our OSHA Hazardous Communications Program

Job specific training consists of specialized training for associates who are expected to come in daily contact with the regulated substance.  This training includes:
 
¿ US DOT Hazardous materials training
¿ OSHA Industrial Truck rules and regulations
¿ In-house material handling and transport
¿ NFPA guidelines for the storage of aerosols

Five-year accident history

There have been no accidental releases of the regulated substance in the past five years that have resulted in any injury to an individual, or damages to properties. 

Emergency response program

The facility is not covered by either OSHA PMS rules, or EPA SPCC rules.  For this reason we have implemented a number of situation specific response procedures which govern the emergency response for each foreseeable emergenc
